byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy and Nicholas Kulish reported from Düsseldorf, Nicola Clark from Paris and Jack Ewing from Montabaur, Germany.
byline.original: By MELISSA EDDY, NICHOLAS KULISH, NICOLA CLARK and JACK EWING

abstract: Investigators say Andreas Lubitz, co-pilot of Germanwings plane that crashed in French Alps, had sought treatment for vision problems that could have ended his career; say police found antidepressants at Lubitz's apartment; investigators and reporters continue to look for clues but many questions remain unanswered.
lead_paragraph: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.

headline.main: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
headline.print_headline: Co-Pilot Sought Treatment for Eyesight, Officials Say
headline.sub: Problems May Have Jeopardized His Ability to Fly

snippet: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.
